posts.cooked: Apologies if this might come across as a stupid question as I don’t have any experience with elevators. But I was looking at some past elevator designs, when I noticed that 254’s 2019 elevator mechanism seems to be pulled up by constant force springs on top of the elevator design, with a chain that connects down to the motors. The chain also appears to be attached to some sort of sprocket on the back (which I briefly saw here Behind the Bumpers FRC254 The Cheesy Poofs 2019 Competition Season - YouTube ), but not to any other part of the carriage, so I’m not sure how that makes the mechanism go up or down. All the other elevators I saw seem to be slightly different, but I can’t seem to figure out how the chain makes the elevator move.

link_counts.title: Behind the Bumpers FRC254 The Cheesy Poofs 2019 Competition Season - YouTube

posts.name: Andrew H.
posts.cooked: Not sure if this answers your question, but here is a thread discussing 254’s technical binder from that year.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Andrew H. | FRC 1506 Alum | Scouting Enthusiast

posts.custom_user_title: Andrew H. | FRC 1506 Alum | Scouting Enthusiast

posts.name: Sean Lavery
posts.cooked:
The constant force spring is being used as a counterbalance to offset the weight of the carriage. By neutralizing the weight (or coming close to it), you reduce the load placed on the motors when you want to maintain a raised position on the elevator (your motors don’t have to stall in order to support the elevator position) and simplify the PID and motion profiling involved in elevator or arm control (you don’t need to account for gravity acting in one direction).

Page 20 of their 2019 technical binder has more details about their elevator in general. You can very briefly see the anchor point between the chain that runs on the elevator and the carriage at 3:21 in the video linked in the OP (before the camera pans around the suction cup) and then again at 3:32 (when the camera pans back around again).

Ah I see, so the anchor point is something like the screenshot below then, where the chain is bolted onto the carriage? image 982×668 80.8 KB

image 982×668 80.8 KB

image 982×668 80.8 KB
Thanks! There were some really helpful CAD screenshots in there, but unfortunately I don’t think I found one with the chain yet…

posts.name: Sean Lavery
posts.cooked: Hard to tell from that screenshot, but I believe that to be the case.

posts.name: Sh1ine
posts.cooked: The Greybots made a video that shows how an elevator works and how to design one.  This is a good resource to check out for more information on your questions.

posts.name: Andrew Torrance
posts.cooked:
What you have pictured is indeed the attachment point.

The design is potentially overbuilt, but we were climbing off the elevator and had the weight/resources. There’s a billet aluminum block with tapped holes that attaches to the tube of the elevator carriage. Off of that block is a steel “comb” that has 4-6 prongs that fit nicely into the gaps of the # 25 chain. The comb attaches to the block with a dowel (to take shear loads) and a large fastener.

Both the block and comb are made on our CNC mill.

There are easier ways to do the attachment. Bolts through the chain works week for many teams. There also exist various online chain tensioners that you could maybe bolt or clamp onto.
That makes so much more sense! Thanks
